chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
When it is said that a person who is sinning receives the benefit of salvation if they turn and lament, it means that even if they lament, they will not be saved unless they also turn. Divine scripture includes both of these requirements for a reason: to show us that both conversion and lamentation are necessary for salvation.

Some people, terrified by their crimes, groan in prayer for their wrongdoings but do not stop their unjust behavior. They admit they have done wrong but do not want to end their bad deeds. They humbly confess their sins before God, yet with a perverse heart, they stubbornly continue committing the same sins they just confessed. Through their wicked deeds, they negate the forgiveness they seek with tearful groans. They ask for healing from the doctor but instead bring more disease upon themselves, leading to their own destruction. Thus, they vainly try to appease the just judge with words, while their unjust actions provoke his fury. Such people never wash away their sins by groaning because they do not stop sinning after their groans. They groan for their crimes and then return to those crimes.

About such people, divine scripture in the book of Ecclesiasticus says: "He who is cleansed from a dead body and touches it again, what does his washing profit him? So, a man who fasts for his sins, and does the same things again, what does his humbling himself profit him? Who will listen to his prayer?" (Ecclesiasticus 34:30-31). Therefore, God rightly says: If you turn and lament, you will be saved. With God, who is both just and good, the prayer of the lamenting person is heard, the weeping of the one asking is attended to, and salvation is granted to the one who weeps if they have turned to God with a contrite heart. It is necessary that God, having mercy, forgives the sinner if the sinner, having turned, acknowledges their wrongdoing.
chunks.original_latin:
Cum dicitur ergo peccanti beneficium salutis accipere
cupienti, quia si conversus fuerit et ingemuerit,
salvus erit; consequenter intelligitur quia, ETIAMSI INGEMUERIT,
 tamen conversus non fuerit, salvus non
erit. Non enim frustra utrumque divinus sermo complexus
est, nisi ut haec duo, id est conversionem et
gemitum, necessaria cognosceremus ad consequendum
salutis effectum. Nonnulli enim scelerum suorum
consideratione perterriti, pro iniquitatibus quidem
suis in oratione gemunt, nec tamen ab iniqua operatione
discedunt. Fatentur se male fecisse, nec ullum
finem volunt malis factis suis imponere. Accusant
humiliter in conspectu Dei peccata quibus tenentur
oppressi, et eadem peccata quae humilitate sermonis
accusant, corde perverso contumaciter cumulant. In
dulgentiam quam lacrymosis gemitibus poscunt, ipsi
 sibi pravis operibus adimunt. Medelam postulant a
medico, et in perniciem suam subrogant adjutorium
morbo. Ac sic inaniter verbis quaerunt placare justum
judicem, quem factis iniquis magis irritant ad furorem. Tales enim nunquam diluunt gemendo peccatum,
quia non desinunt peccare post gemitum. Pro
criminibus namque gemunt; et post gemitum ad crimina
redeunt. De talibus in libro Ecclesiastico Scriptura
divina sic loquitur: Qui baptizatur a mortuo, et
iterum tangit illum, quid proficit lavatio ejus? Sic
homo qui jejunat pro peccatis suis, et iterum eadem
faciens, quid proficit humiliando se? Orationem ejus
quis exaudiet (Eccli XXXIV 30 31)? Rectissime igitur
dicit Deus homini: Si conversus fueris et ingemueris,
salvus eris. Apud Deum quippe severum et bonum
tunc oratio gementis auditur, tunc poscentis fletus
 attenditur, tunc flenti conceditur salus, si fuerit ad
Deum contriti cordis humilitate conversus. Necesse
est enim ut Deus peccatori misertus ignoscat, si tamen
peccator iniquitatem suam conversus agnoscat.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
Finally, David found divine mercy because he turned back with a humble and contrite heart, acknowledging and condemning his wrongdoing. He did not delay in punishing himself through repentance for the wrongful desire that led to his fall. For if he did not punish himself for his guilt, he would undoubtedly be punished.

Thus, he acknowledged his crime and turned to repentance, fearing the punishment that would come if he were condemned. Through repentance, he vindicated himself by acknowledging what he wanted the Lord to forgive.

When he said, "Have mercy on me, O God, according to your great mercy, and according to the multitude of your tender mercies, blot out my iniquity; wash me more and more from my injustice, and cleanse me from my sin" (Psalm 50:1-2), he immediately added, "For I acknowledge my iniquity, and my sin is always before me" (Psalm 50:4).

He acknowledged his iniquity not to increase it by sinning more, but to wipe it away through repentance. Thus, the dominion of sin, brought in by guilty pleasure, was removed by true conversion.

Because David groaned from his whole heart and turned back, he was immediately made safe, fulfilling the command through the prophet: "If you turn back and groan, you will be saved."
chunks.original_latin:
Denique divinam misericordiam 369 propterea David
sanctus efficaciter invenit, quia conversus per
humilitatem contriti cordis, quod male fecerat agnoscendo
damnavit, nec distulit punire poenitendo mali
operis cupiditatem in qua fuerat lapsus; quia si non puniret
unde reus tenebatur, procul dubio ipse puniretur. Suum ergo facinus agnovit conversus in poenitentiam,
metuit ne damnatus agnovisset poenam. Ipse
in se poenitens vindicabat agnoscendo, quod ignosci
sibi volebat a Domino. Denique cum dixisset: Miserere
mei, Deus, secundum magnam misericordiam tuam,
 et secundum multitudinem miserationum tuarum dele
iniquitatem meam; Magis magisque lava me ab injustitia
mea, et a delicto meo munda me (Psal L 1 2);
statim secutus adjunxit: Quoniam iniquitatem meam
ego agnosco, delictum meum coram me est semper
(Ibid 4). Agnoscebat iniquitatem suam, non ut peccando
magis augeret, sed ut poenitendo dilueret; atque
ita dominationem peccati, quam delectatio culpabilis
invexit, conversio vera submovit. Et quia ingemuit
David ex toto corde conversus, continuo salvus
est factus, atque ita in eo completum est quod
per prophetam praecipitur: Si conversus fueris et ingemueris,
salvus eris.
